title: Chapter 245
content: # Chapter 245 "Come out!" Earl Zebra burst into his great hall. Nine shadows materialized from the darkness. The Black Arrows had served his family for generations. Their reputation was flawless. Not once had they failed an assassination. "Kill the man who was just here." Earl Zebra's voice cracked with rage. "Bring me back the Black Quartz Earrings." "Yes, my lord." The assassins vanished. Earl Zebra blinked. One moment they stood before him. The next, nothing. He couldn't pinpoint the instant they disappeared. *That bastard doesn't stand a chance.* A twisted smile spread across his face. No target had ever survived the Black Arrows. He began humming, already imagining Grid's corpse. "Nyang." A small cat padded into the hall. Its fur was smooth and black, except for the four white paws and tail tip that gleamed like fresh snow. *C-Cute!* Earl Zebra froze. The cat possessed an absolute charm that seized even his deranged mind. For one precious moment, his cruelty evaporated. He wanted nothing more than to keep this creature by his side forever. The moment passed. "Where are the guards?" He bellowed at the walls. "Why can't you keep a beast out of my hall? Do you want to die?" "I-I'm sorry, my lord." The soldiers who rushed in looked pale. They had been standing watch. Nothing should have gotten past them. Not even an ant. "Stop gawking. Get rid of it." The soldiers lunged for the cat. Despite its chubby frame, it moved like lightning. It bounced around the great hall as though it owned the place. "Heok?" Earl Zebra and his men stared. Small wings had sprouted from the cat's back. A tiny horn protruded from its forehead. "M-Monster...!" Earl Zebra finally understood. He raised his hands to defend himself. Too slow. Too clumsy. "Kiyaaah!" Papat! Pa pa pa pat! The cat's paws became a blur. Pain exploded across Earl Zebra's face. His skin burned. "Kuaaaaak!" His scream echoed through the stone chamber. Blood poured down his mangled face. "H-Hik." The soldiers went rigid with terror. Earl Zebra's wrath would fall on them now. They had failed to stop the creature. *He'll torture us.* *What do we do?* *Why us?* The soldiers exchanged glances. Their eyes drifted to their spears. They began inching toward Earl Zebra, who writhed in agony on the floor. "Y-You...!" Earl Zebra had never known suffering. Noble blood had shielded him from hardship his entire life. This was his first real injury. And his own men were closing in. "How dare you threaten your master! This is treason! I'll cut off your limbs! You'll all die screaming!" His threats fell on deaf ears. The soldiers raised their spears. Earl Zebra changed tactics. "Put down your weapons. I'll forgive you. I'll reward you. Just calm down." "You think we'll believe you?" One soldier spat. "We've seen you lie to the people you torture!" "I've hated you from the start! Human butcher! The world is better without you!" "You killed my cousin. She was only fifteen, you son of a bitch." Suppressed rage boiled over. They had nothing left to lose. If they didn't kill him, he would kill them. The soldiers knew there was no going back. Puk! Puk puk puk! "Y-You! Kuheook!" The man who was crueler than any demon choked on his own blood. "Nyang." The cat, architect of this chaos, sauntered out of the great hall. *** "Was this what you aimed for?" On the outer walls, Kiki lowered her head. She had just used her Hawk Eyes skill to observe the castle interior. Veradin shook his head. "No. I only wanted the Slaughterer's bones." He couldn't know why Grid had come to visit Earl Zebra. The Slaughterer was a bounty monster sought by many rankers. Perhaps Grid had come to raid it? Veradin had predicted Grid's presence. He hadn't warned Earl Zebra. The result was Grid claiming the Slaughterer's corpse. So far, everything had gone according to plan. But Earl Zebra's death? That was unexpected. Technically, the soldiers had killed him. Yet the black cat that sparked the incident clearly belonged to Grid. "Interesting." Was Grid really acting on behalf of people from another kingdom? A strange smile crossed Veradin's face. "What should we do?" Kiki asked. "There will be an uproar." The empire wouldn't ignore a murdered noble. They would send investigators. The atmosphere would turn bloody. That wasn't the only problem. Earl Zebra's son was still young and emotionally unstable from watching his father's cruelty. He was easily manipulated. The other nobles wouldn't trust such a boy with territory. A vicious power struggle would erupt. "Veradin? Are you listening? Shouldn't we report Grid now?" "Dismissed." "What?" Kiki stared at him. Grid was their enemy. He had hurt their guild. He had destroyed Earl Zebra's territory, their guild's home. Yet Veradin was letting him go? Veradin explained. "We'll arrest the soldiers who killed Earl Zebra. We'll gain a massive achievement. Then we can increase our influence and install Earl Zebra's son as lord." He was playing a longer game. "This is an opportunity." Veradin believed this would let him eventually absorb Earl Zebra's territory. He would give this estate to his master, Agnus. *** Grid waited in a thicket beyond the castle walls. *I wanted to kill him myself.* Earl Zebra was wicked beyond redemption. Grid had been through countless adventures. He had never encountered someone so brutal. But killing the earl personally was too dangerous. The empire would hunt him. That would make reaching Asmophel difficult. It would also put the Eternal Kingdom in a bad position. If he had known Veradin was an imperial noble, Grid wouldn't have touched the White Wolf Guild. But he didn't know. He couldn't feel grateful that Veradin hadn't reported him. "Grid is a good person? Then you punished a bad person?" Randy was questioning the division between good and evil. Grid looked at his companion, satisfied by how much Randy grew each day. "I'm not good." That was true. Grid wasn't a good man. He wouldn't sacrifice himself unless it was for his colleagues. But he had a minimum level of conscience. He couldn't ignore those living in fear of Earl Zebra. If he lacked strength, he might have walked away for his own comfort. *I'm no longer weak.* He was willing to help if he could. As long as it didn't harm him. This was Grid's evolution. It wasn't quite justice. But it wasn't truly contemptible either. Grid sensed movement. Uninvited guests were approaching their position. With over **1,400** Insight, detecting them was easy. "Zebra's dogs." Grid measured assassins against one standard. Faker. These men weren't in Faker's league. In other words, Grid didn't acknowledge most assassins in the world. It wasn't arrogance. His judgment was sound. Assassins relied on stealth and speed. But with Grid's high Insight and absurd defense, threatening him was nearly impossible. They would need at least Faker's skill to pose a real danger. Susuk. The assassins crept closer, unaware they had been detected. They closed the distance. Daggers aimed for Grid's throat. Chaaeng! Golden blades intercepted the strike. "Cute tricks." "...!" The assassins' faces remained blank. Inside, they reeled with shock. *He noticed us? Impossible.* They struck again. Useless. Puok! "Kuaaaak!" The golden blades flew from nowhere, burying themselves in an assassin's thigh. > **[Critical!]** > **[You have dealt 1,590 damage to the target.]** *Only that much damage, even on a critical hit.* Pavranium was the strongest mineral. A weapon forged entirely from it would surpass even Failure. But these blades contained only trace amounts. Their attack power was limited. *Minor needs to find those western labyrinths.* He needed more pavranium. Minor had a heavy responsibility. As Grid pondered this, the assassins grew wary. *He has backup!* Grid had been alone when he entered the castle. Now a girl accompanied him, and someone was throwing golden blades. They needed to find the hidden guard. But no matter how hard they looked, they detected nothing. Grid smiled. He pointed at the sky. "Above." "...?" The assassins looked up. The golden blades moved on their own. *Artifact!* The assassins whirled back toward Grid. "Keok..." "Ugh..." Three of them were already impaled on a blue greatsword. "What is this?" This was absurd! "Are we being hunted?" Past Grid and present Grid shared one trait. He showed no mercy to enemies. "Don't waste my time. Die quietly." The iron mask covering half his face seemed to be crying at first glance. Now it looked like it was smiling. The assassins experienced the greatest terror of their lives.
